head.supplied: [Delegate, 26 May 1887] ¶ ¶ [...] ¶ ¶ I beg to point out that what at present I send under the name of Euc. Gunnii must be taken (for the present) provisionally, for it is only this evening that I r...

div.p: MRS 202/148 special bundle, collector, Archives of the Museum of Applied Arts and Sciences, Ultimo, New South Wales.

I beg to point out that what at present I send under the name of Euc. Gunnii must be taken (for the present) provisionally, for it is only this evening that I received from the Baron the "return" of some plants collected on the top of Tingiringi Mntn,
Mountain. amongst which is a Eucalypt quite different in leaves and fruit which he names Eucal. Gunnii, though two years ago he named the species of which I now send you Leaves, Bark & Gum also Euc. G. and the two species are widely different.

I must tell you that tomorrow morning I shall start for the Tingiringi Mntns again, and that quite unexpectedly in response to Baron von Müllers most urgent desire, for amongst the plants collected during my last ascend, there is one which is quite new, but of which at the time I could find neither flower nor fruit, though I tried hard to find some. At that time I intended to ascend the mountain again the following day, in order to try again, but snow and rain prevented me. The weather promises fine now, but I am 25 miles from the spot, therefore I have a lot of things to do yet to night. Baron von Müller thinks that I shall find the plant yet of the size of a large shrub or even tree, and he has reminded me that, should such be case, you would be pleased to obtain a piece of the timber of it. The specimen of timber would however have to be very small, as I have to go on foot and the way of getting there is very rough.
